landlord_tenant_relationship.reasoning: Complaint pleads a tenancy (lease for Apt. 2 beginning June 1, 2022), payment of rent, and identifies Defendant as owner/landlord of the building — facts that plainly establish a landlord-tenant relationship.

act_or_omission_by_landlord.reasoning: Complaint alleges multiple complaints to Defendant, that he spoke once to the upstairs tenants and thereafter declined further meaningful action (stating he “can’t control how people live”), i.e., an alleged omission/failure to take reasonable steps to abate the disturbance.

substantial_interference.reasoning: Complaint alleges frequent and severe disturbances (heavy stomping at night, loud late-night music, furniture-moving noises), ongoing and continuous, and pleads concrete effects (chronic loss of sleep, decreased functioning) sufficient to allege a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.

causation.reasoning: Complaint links the ongoing noise to the upstairs occupants and alleges Defendant had actual notice (5–6 complaints) and the ability to act as landlord/owner; it further alleges the landlord’s failure to act allowed the disturbance to continue, which sufficiently pleads causation at the pleading stage.

damages.reasoning: Complaint alleges specific economic and non-economic harms (reduced sleep, written warning at work, $40/month prescription, costs for earplugs/white-noise machine, loss of use/enjoyment) and seeks $2,500, adequately pleading damages.
